abstract.text: Tags: Atom, Blog, Daily, Evernote, imdone

inlineContent.text: Today is the first day of my switch to a more capable all-in-one productivity tool! I feel like I have tried so many things yet so few have stuck. I hope this one does!

. It did a lot for me. However, it got convoluted. The first hint that this solution was doomed was the bad reminders functionality. The second was the never updated penultimate support. To this day, the drawing just does not feel natural.

. It was shiny and new. However, when I think about the reason of why I started it (to use git as a task database), that never paid off. Mainly, the goal was learning git while using it as my note taking system.

. It has worked for me for the better part of 4 years! It was great for the kanban view but I was trying to hack a productivity system out of text. I did this semi consistently, but the friction of keeping it up to date has been hard. You have to sync every computer you use manually via push and pull. You need Atom. You Need the Mac app. Resolve conflicts. Add metadata by hand. The system was falling apart at the seams…
Hopefully, Notion does all of this. From what I heard, it enables the second brain method. It also allows for you to get all areas of your life together into one place. This was the goal behind
, a concept I had about 9 years ago. I never fleshed it out  because I wanted to get professional iOS experience instead, but the concept has always been at the back of my mind.
I wish the Notion team the best of luck.

doc://me.rismay.site/documentation/Risma.title: Swift’s Struct Packing and Memory Dynamics, Inherited from C
Navigating the Performance Penalties of Swift Type Inference

abstract.text: In the world of programming languages, Swift has emerged as a dynamic and versatile option. Its type inference feature, while powerful, isn’t without its quirks. Like any technological innovation, Swift’s type inference has its own set of performance considerations that developers should be aware of. In this blog post, we’ll delve into the fascinating realm of Swift’s type inference and explore how it can sometimes impose performance penalties.

I previously posted that I returned my Late 2013 13” rMBP after I encountered the dreaded unresponsive keyboard glitch. This is a bit disingenuous because the ultimate reason I returned the notebook was to purchase a more powerful version of the same laptop after the Keyboard/Trackpad problems were confirmed to be software issues. However, when I went to look at my buying options, I discover that Apple was offering the original 2012 15” rMBP for $1600. That’s $500 off for a laptop that comes with a 1 year warranty. This post is simply to help those wondering: Should you pay $100 more for a refurbished original 15” Retina Macbook Pro vs a new Late 2013 13” MacBook Pro Retina?

doc://me.rismay.site/documentation/Risma.title: $1500 13” Late 2013 rMBP vs $1600 15” 2012 rMBP? Portability vs Performance
